column1: Brisbane ( (listen) BRIZ-bən) is the capital of and the most populated city in the Australian state of Queensland
column2: and the third most populous city in Australia. Brisbane's metropolitan area has a population of over 2.5 million
column3: and the South East Queensland metropolitan region
column4: centred on Brisbane
column5: encompasses a population of more than 3.6 million. The Brisbane central business district stands on the historic European settlement and is situated inside a peninsula of the Brisbane River
column6: about 15 kilometres (9 miles) from its mouth at Moreton Bay
column7: a bay of the Coral Sea. The metropolitan area extends in all directions along the hilly floodplain of the Brisbane River Valley between Moreton Bay and the Taylor and D'Aguilar mountain ranges. It sprawls across several of Australia's most populous local government areas (LGAs)—most centrally the City of Brisbane
column8: which is by far the most populous LGA in the nation. The demonym of Brisbane is "Brisbanite"
column10: "River City" and "Brisvegas".One of the oldest cities in Australia
column11: Brisbane was founded upon the ancient traditional lands of the Jagera people
column13: who named the area Meanjin. Named after the Brisbane River on which it is located—which in turn takes its name from Scotsman Sir Thomas Brisbane
column14: the Governor of New South Wales at the time of the city's founding—the area was chosen as a place for secondary offenders from the Sydney Colony. The Moreton Bay penal settlement was founded in 1824 at Redcliffe
column15: 28 kilometres (17 mi) north of the central business district
column16: but was soon abandoned and moved to North Quay in 1825
column17: opening to free settlement in 1842. Brisbane was chosen as the capital when Queensland was proclaimed a separate colony from New South Wales in 1859. During World War II
column18: Brisbane played a central role in the Allied campaign and served as the South West Pacific headquarters for United States Army General Douglas MacArthur.A diverse city with 32.2% of its metropolitan population being foreign born
column19: Brisbane is classified as a global city (Beta +)
column20: and ranks highly in ratings of liveable cities. Brisbane is well known for its distinct Queenslander architecture which forms much of the city's built heritage. The city is noted for its cuisine brunches
column22: and rooftop bar scene. Brisbane was also the origin of the Anzac Day tradition through the works of Canon David John Garland.

column1: A transportation hub
column2: Brisbane is served by a large suburban rail network
column3: popular bus and ferry networks as well as Australia's third-busiest airport and seaport.

column1: Brisbane is a popular tourist destination. Major landmarks and attractions include South Bank Parklands
column2: the Queensland Cultural Centre (home to the Queensland Museum
column3: the Queensland Art Gallery
column4: the Gallery of Modern Art and other institutions)
column5: the Story Bridge
column6: Fortitude Valley
column10: Mount Coot-tha Reserve and Moreton Bay.

column1: == History ==
=== Prehistory ===
Aboriginal Australians lived in coastal South East Queensland (SEQ) for 22
column2: 000 years
column3: with an estimated population between 6
column5: 000 individuals before European settlers arrived in the 1820s. At this time the Brisbane area was inhabited by the Jagera people
column6: including the Turrbal group
column7: who knew the area that is now the central business district as Mian-jin
column8: meaning "place shaped as a spike". Archaeological evidence suggests frequent habitation around the Brisbane River
column9: and notably at the site now known as Musgrave Park.Jagara (also known as Turrbal
column12: and Yuggera) and Yugarabul (also known as Ugarapul and Yuggerabul) are Australian Aboriginal languages of South-East Queensland.  There is some uncertainty over the status of Jagara as a language
column13: dialect or perhaps a group or clan within the present-day local-government boundaries of City of Ipswich
column14: Lockyer Valley Region and the Somerset Region. The languages of Greater Brisbane are related – there is uncertainty over which dialects belong to which language. The Yugarabul language region includes the landscape within the local-government boundaries of City of Brisbane
column15: City of Ipswich and the Scenic Rim Region.

column1: === 18th century ===
Matthew Flinders initially explored the Moreton Bay area on behalf of European colonisers. On 17 July 1799
column2: Flinders landed at present-day Woody Point
column3: which he named "Red Cliff Point" after the red-coloured cliffs visible from the bay.

column1: === 19th century ===
In 1823 the Governor of New South Wales
column2: Sir Thomas Brisbane
column3: gave instructions for the development of a new northern penal settlement be developed
column4: and an exploration party led by John Oxley further explored Moreton Bay in November 1823.

column1: Oxley claimed
column2: named
column3: and explored the Brisbane River as far as Goodna
column4: 20 km (12 mi) upstream from the present-day central business district of Brisbane. Oxley recommended Red Cliff Point for the new colony
column5: reporting that ships could land at any tide and easily get close to the shore. The convict settlement party landed in Redcliffe on 13 September 1824
column6: under the command of Lieutenant Henry Miller - the group included 14 soldiers (some with wives and children) and 29 convicts. However
column7: the settlers abandoned this site after a year and moved to an area on the Brisbane River now known as North Quay
column9: which offered a more reliable water-supply. The newly selected Brisbane region
column11: was plagued by mosquitos.After visiting the Redcliffe settlement
column12: Sir Thomas Brisbane then travelled 45 km (28 mi) up the Brisbane River in December 1824. Governor Brisbane stayed overnight in a tent and often landed ashore
column13: thus bestowing upon the future Brisbane City the distinction of being the only Australian capital city visited by its namesake. Chief Justice Forbes gave the new settlement the name of "Edenglassie" before it was named "Brisbane".Non-convict European settlement of the Brisbane region commenced in 1838 and the population grew strongly thereafter
column14: with free settlers soon far outstripping the convict population. German missionaries settled at Zions Hill
column16: five years before Brisbane was officially declared a free settlement. The band consisted of ministers Christopher Eipper (1813–1894)
column25: Doege and Schneider. They were allocated 260 hectares and set about establishing the mission
column26: which became known as the German Station. Later in the 1860s many German immigrants from the Uckermark region in Prussia as well as from other German regions settled in the areas of Bethania
column27: Beenleigh and the Darling Downs. These immigrants were selected and assisted through immigration programs established by John Dunmore Lang and Johann Christian Heussler and were offered free passage
column29: and selections of land.The penal settlement under the control of Captain Patrick Logan (Commandant from 1826 to 1830) flourished
column30: with the numbers of convicts increasing dramatically from around 200 to over 1
column31: 000 men. He developed a substantial settlement of brick and stone buildings
column32: complete with school and hospital. He formed additional outstations and made several important journeys of exploration. Logan became infamous for his extreme use of the cat o' nine tails on convicts. The maximum allowed limit of lashes was 50; however
column33: Logan regularly applied sentences of 150 lashes.Between 1824 and 1842
column35: 400 men and 145 women were detained at the Moreton Bay convict settlement under the control of military commandants.Free settlers entered the area from 1835
column37: Robert Dixon had begun work on the first plan of Brisbane Town
column38: in anticipation of future development. Letters patent dated 6 June 1859
column39: proclaimed by Sir George Ferguson Bowen on 10 December 1859
column40: separated Queensland from New South Wales
column41: whereupon Sir George became Queensland's first governor
column42: with Brisbane chosen as the capital.In 1893 Brisbane was affected by the Black February flood
column43: when the Brisbane River burst its banks on three occasions in February and again in June in the same year
column44: with the city receiving more than a year's rainfall during February 1893
column45: leaving much of the city's population homeless.

column1: === 20th century ===
Over 20 small municipalities and shires were amalgamated in 1925 to form the City of Brisbane
column2: governed by the Brisbane City Council. A significant year for Brisbane was 1930
column3: with the completion of Brisbane City Hall
column4: then the city's tallest building and the Shrine of Remembrance
column5: in ANZAC Square
column6: which has become Brisbane's main war memorial. These historic buildings
column7: along with the Story Bridge which opened in 1940
column8: are key landmarks that help define the architectural character of the city.

column1: During World War II
column2: Brisbane became central to the Allied campaign when the AMP Building (now called MacArthur Central) was used as the South West Pacific headquarters for General Douglas MacArthur
column3: chief of the Allied Pacific forces
column4: until his headquarters were moved to Hollandia in August 1944. MacArthur had previously rejected use of the University of Queensland complex as his headquarters
column5: as the distinctive bends in the river at St Lucia could have aided enemy bombers. Also used as a headquarters by the American troops during World War II was the T & G Building. About one million US troops passed through Australia during the war
column6: as the primary co-ordination point for the South West Pacific. In 1942
column7: Brisbane was the site of a violent clash between visiting US military personnel and Australian servicemen and civilians
column8: which resulted in one death and hundreds of injuries. This incident became known colloquially as the Battle of Brisbane.Post-war Brisbane had developed a "big country town" stigma
column9: an image the city's politicians and marketers were very keen to remove. In the late 1950s
column10: an anonymous poet known as The Brisbane Bard generated much attention to the city which helped shake this stigma. Despite steady growth
column11: Brisbane's development was punctuated by infrastructure problems. The state government under Joh Bjelke-Petersen began a major programme of change and urban renewal
column12: beginning with the central business district and inner suburbs. Trams in Brisbane were a popular mode of public transport until the network was closed in 1969
column13: leaving Melbourne and one line in Adelaide as the last Australian state capitals to operate trams until Sydney began operation of a new system in 1997.

column1: The 1974 Brisbane flood was a major disaster which temporarily crippled the city. During this era
column2: Brisbane grew and modernised
column3: rapidly becoming a destination of interstate migration. Some of Brisbane's popular landmarks were lost to development in controversial circumstances
column4: including the Bellevue Hotel in 1979 and Cloudland in 1982. Major public works included the Riverside Expressway
column5: the Gateway Bridge
column6: and later
column8: starting with the Queensland Art Gallery.

column1: Between 1968 and 1987
column2: when Queensland was governed by Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen
column3: whose government was characterised by strong social conservatism and the use of police force against demonstrators
column4: and which ended with the Fitzgerald Inquiry into police corruption
column5: Brisbane developed a counterculture focussed on the University of Queensland
column6: street marches and Brisbane punk rock music.

column1: Brisbane hosted the 1982 Commonwealth Games and the 1988 World Exposition (known locally as World Expo 88). These events were accompanied by a scale of public expenditure
column2: construction
column3: and development not previously seen in the state of Queensland. Brisbane's population growth far exceeded the national average in the last two decades of the 20th century
column4: with a high level of interstate migration from Victoria and New South Wales.

column1: === 21st century ===
After three decades of record population growth
column2: Brisbane was hit again by a major flood in January 2011. The Brisbane River did not reach the same height as the previous 1974 flood
column3: but still caused extensive damage and disruption to the city.Brisbane also hosted major international events including the final Goodwill Games in 2001
column4: the Rugby League World Cup Final in 2008 and again in 2017
column5: as well as the 2014 G20 Brisbane summit.

column1: Population growth has continued to be among the highest of the Australian capital cities in the first two decades of the 21st century
column2: and major infrastructure including the Howard Smith Wharves
column3: Roma Street Parklands
column4: Queens Wharf
column5: the Brisbane Riverwalk
column6: the Queen's Wharf casino and resort precinct
column13: Redcliffe Peninsula and Cross River Rail railway lines have been completed or are under construction.

column1: == Geography and environment ==
Brisbane is in the southeast corner of Queensland. The city is centred along the Brisbane River
column2: and its eastern suburbs line the shores of Moreton Bay
column3: a bay of the Coral Sea in the Pacific Ocean. The greater Brisbane region is on the coastal plain east of the Great Dividing Range
column4: with the Taylor and D'Aguilar ranges extending into the metropolitan area. Brisbane's metropolitan area sprawls along the Moreton Bay floodplain between the Gold and Sunshine coasts
column5: approximately from Caboolture in the north to Beenleigh in the south
column6: and across to Ipswich in the south west.

column1: The Brisbane River is a wide tidal estuary and its waters throughout most of the metropolitan area are brackish and navigable. The river takes a winding course through the metropolitan area with many steep curves from the southwest to its mouth at Moreton Bay in the east. The metropolitan area is also traversed by several other rivers and creeks including the North Pine and South Pine rivers in the northern suburbs
column2: which converge to form the Pine River estuary at Bramble Bay
column3: the Caboolture River further north
column4: the Logan and Albert rivers in the south-eastern suburbs
column5: and tributaries of the Brisbane River including the Bremer River in the south-western suburbs
column6: Breakfast Creek in the inner-north
column9: Bulimba Creek in the inner south-east and Moggill Creek in the west. The city is on a low-lying floodplain
column10: with the risk of flooding addressed by the Brisbane City Council's FloodSmart Future Strategy 2012–2031.The waters of Moreton Bay are sheltered from large swells by Moreton
column12: so whilst the bay can become rough in windy conditions
column13: the waves at Moreton Bay beaches are generally not surfable. Unsheltered surf beaches lie on the eastern coasts of Moreton
column14: Stradbroke and Bribie islands islands and on the Gold Coast and Sunshine Coast to the north and south. The southern part of Moreton Bay also contains smaller islands such as St Helena Island

column1: The city of Brisbane is hilly. The urban area
column2: including the central business district
column3: are partially elevated by spurs of the Herbert Taylor Range
column4: such as the summit of Mount Coot-tha
column5: reaching up to 300 m (980 ft) and the smaller Enoggera Hill. The D'Aguilar National Park
column6: encompassing the D'Aguilar Range
column7: bounds the north-west of Brisbane's built-up area
column8: and contains the taller peaks of Mount Nebo
column12: Mount Samson and Mount Mee. Other prominent rises in Brisbane are Mount Gravatt and nearby Toohey Mountain. Mount Petrie at 170 m (560 ft) and the lower rises of Highgate Hill
column13: Mount Ommaney
column15: and Whites Hill are dotted across the city.

column1: Much of the rock upon which Brisbane is located is the characteristic Brisbane tuff
column2: a form of welded ignimbrite
column3: which is most prominently found at the Kangaroo Point Cliffs at Kangaroo Point and the New Farm Cliffs on the Petrie Bight reach of the Brisbane River. The stone was used in the construction of historical buildings such as the Commissariat Store and Cathedral of St Stephen
column4: and the roadside kerbs in inner areas of Brisbane are still manufactured of Brisbane tuff.

column1: === Ecology ===
Brisbane is located within the South East Queensland biogeographic region
column2: and is home to numerous Eucalyptus varieties. Trees considered iconic to Brisbane include the Moreton Bay fig
column3: a very large evergreen banyan with imposing buttress roots named for the region which are often lit with decorative lights in the inner city
column4: as well as the jacaranda
column5: a subtropical tree native to South America which line avenues and parks throughout Brisbane and bloom with purple flowers during October
column6: referred to locally as 'jacaranda season'. Other trees common to the metropolitan area include Moreton Bay chestnut
column9: weeping lilli pilli and Bangalow palm. Some of the banks of the Brisbane River and Moreton Bay are home to mangrove wetlands.

column1: Brisbane is home to numerous bird species
column2: with common species including rainbow lorikeets
column3: kookaburras
column4: galahs
column5: Australian white ibises
column6: Australian brushturkeys
column8: Australian magpies and noisy miners. Common reptiles include common garden skinks
column10: bearded dragons and blue-tongued lizards. Common ringtail possums and flying foxes are common in parks and yards throughout the city
column13: golden orb-weaver spiders and St Andrew's Cross spiders. The Brisbane River is home to many fish species including yellowfin bream
column16: and bull sharks. The waters of Moreton Bay are home to dugongs
column21: Moreton Bay bugs and numerous shellfish species.

column1: === Climate ===
Brisbane has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification: Cfa) with hot
column2: wet summers and moderately dry
column3: moderately warm winters. Brisbane experiences an annual mean minimum of 16.6 °C (62 °F) and mean maximum of 26.6 °C (80 °F)
column4: making it Australia's second-hottest capital city after Darwin. Seasonality is not pronounced
column5: and average maximum temperatures of above 26 °C (79 °F) persist from October through to April.

column1: Due to its proximity to the Coral Sea and a warm ocean current
column2: Brisbane's overall temperature variability is somewhat less than most Australian capitals. Summers are long
column3: hot
column4: and wet
column5: but temperatures only occasionally reach 35 °C (95 °F) or more. Eighty percent of summer days record a maximum temperature of 27 to 33 °C (81 to 91 °F). Winters are short and warm
column6: with average maximums of about 22 °C (72 °F); maximum temperatures below 20 °C (68 °F) are rare.

column1: The city's highest recorded temperature was 43.2 °C (109.8 °F) on Australia Day 1940 at the Brisbane Regional Office
column2: with the highest temperature at the current station being 41.7 °C (107.1 °F) on 22 February 2004; but temperatures above 38 °C (100 °F) are uncommon. On 19 July 2007
column3: Brisbane's temperature fell below the freezing point for the first time since records began
column4: registering −0.1 °C (31.8 °F) at the airport station. The city station has never dropped below 2 °C (36 °F)
column5: with the average coldest night during winter being around 6 °C (43 °F)
column6: however locations in the west of the metropolitan area such as Ipswich have dropped as low as −5 °C (23 °F) with heavy ground frost.In 2009
column7: Brisbane recorded its hottest winter day (from June to August) at 35.4 °C (95.7 °F) on 24 August; The average July day however is around 22 °C (72 °F) with sunny skies and low humidity
column9: whilst maximum temperatures below 18 °C (64 °F) are uncommon and usually associated with brief periods of cloud and winter rain. The highest minimum temperature ever recorded in Brisbane was 28.0 °C (82.4 °F) on 29 January 1940 and again on 21 January 2017
column10: whilst the lowest maximum temperature was 10.2 °C (50.4 °F) on 12 August 1954.Annual precipitation is ample. From November to March
column12: with the more severe events accompanied by large damaging hail stones
column13: torrential rain and destructive winds. On an annual basis
column14: Brisbane averages 124 clear days. Dewpoints in the summer average at around 20 °C (68 °F); the apparent temperature exceeds 30 °C (86 °F) on almost all summer days. Brisbane's wettest day occurred on 21 January 1887
column15: when 465 millimetres (18.3 in) of rain fell on the city
column16: the highest maximum daily rainfall of Australia's capital cities. The wettest month on record was February 1893
column19: although in the last 30 years the record monthly rainfall has been a much lower 479.8 millimetres (18.89 in) from December 2010. Very occasionally a whole month will pass with no recorded rainfall
column20: the last time this happened was August 1991. The city has suffered three major floods since its founding
column22: January 1974 (partially a result of Cyclone Wanda)
column23: and January 2011 (partially a result of Cyclone Tasha).

column1: Brisbane is within the southern reaches of the tropical cyclone risk zone. Full strength tropical cyclones rarely affect Brisbane
column2: but they do occasionally. The biggest risk is ex-tropical cyclones which can cause destructive winds and flooding rains.The average annual temperature of the sea ranges from 21.0 °C (69.8 °F) in July to 27.0 °C (80.6 °F) in February.

column1: == Urban structure ==
The Brisbane central business district (CBD
column2: colloquially referred to as 'the city') lies in a curve of the Brisbane river. The CBD covers 2.2 km2 (0.8 sq mi) and is walkable. Most central streets are named after members of the House of Hanover. Queen Street (named in honour of Queen Victoria) is Brisbane's traditional main street and contains its largest pedestrian mall
column3: the Queen Street Mall. Streets named after female members (Adelaide
column4: Alice
column5: Ann
column6: Charlotte
column9: and Mary) run parallel to Queen Street and perpendicular to streets named after male members (Albert

column1: The CBD's squares include King George Square
column2: Post Office Square and ANZAC Square (home to the city's central war memorial).

column1: Brisbane's metropolitan area is broadly and colloquially divided into the 'northside' and the 'southside'
column2: with the dividing line being the Brisbane River
column3: as crossing one of the 15 bridges across the river is required to travel to the opposite side by land transport. This results in many areas which are south of the CBD being classified as located in the 'northside'
column4: and vice versa
column5: as a result of the river's winding trajectory. In addition to being classified as located on the 'northside' or 'southside' there are further broad and colloquial regions such as the 'westside' for some areas to the southwest of the CBD and the 'bayside' for areas located on the coast of Moreton Bay.

column1: Greater Brisbane had a density of 148 inhabitants per square kilometre (380/sq mi) in 2016. Like most Australian and North American cities
column2: Brisbane has a sprawling metropolitan area which takes in excess of one hour to traverse either north to south or east to west by car without traffic.

column1: From the 1970s onwards
column2: there has been a large increase in the construction of apartment developments
column3: including mid-rise and high rise buildings
column4: which has quickened in the 21st century. At the 2016 census
column5: 76.4% of residents lived in separate houses
column6: 12.6% lived in apartments

column1: === Parklands ===
Brisbane's major parklands include the riverside City Botanic Gardens at Gardens Point
column2: Roma Street Parkland
column3: the 27-hectare Victoria Park at Spring Hill and Herston
column4: South Bank Parklands along the river at South Bank
column5: the Brisbane Botanic Gardens at Mount Coot-tha and the riverside New Farm Park at New Farm.

column1: There are many national parks surrounding the Brisbane metropolitan area. The D'Aguilar National Park is a major national park along the northwest of the metropolitan area in the D'Aguilar Range. The Glass House Mountains National Park is located to the north of the metropolitan area in the Glass House Mountains and provides green space between the Brisbane metropolitan area and the Sunshine Coast. The Tamborine National Park at Tamborine Mountain is located in the Gold Coast hinterland to the south of the metropolitan area.
The eastern metropolitan area is built along the Moreton Bay Marine Park
column2: encompassing Moreton Bay. Significant areas of Moreton
column3: North Stradbroke and Bribie islands also covered by the Moreton Island National Park
column4: Naree Budjong Djara National Park and the Bribie Island National Park respectively. The Boondall Wetlands in the suburb of Boondall include 1
column5: 100 hectares of wetlands which are home to mangroves and shorebirds as well as walking tracks.

column1: === Architecture ===
Brisbane has retained many heritage buildings
column2: some of which date back to the 1820s
column3: including The Old Windmill in Wickham Park
column4: built by convict labour in 1824
column5: which is the oldest surviving building in Brisbane
column6: and the Commissariat Store on William Street
column8: was originally used as a grainhouse
column9: and is now the home of the Royal Historical Society of Brisbane and contains a museum. Other 19th and early 20th-century buildings of architectural significance include the Treasury Building
column13: MacArthur Chambers
column14: The Mansions and the National Australia Bank Building.

column1: Brisbane is the origin of a distinctive architectural style known as Queenslander architecture
column2: which developed in the 1840s and characterises the majority of pre-war homes built in the metropolitan area. Queenslander homes typically feature timber construction with large verandahs
column3: gabled corrugated iron roofs
column4: high ceilings. Most of these houses are elevated on stumps (also called "stilts")
column5: traditionally built of timber
column6: which allow for a void under the houses which aid in cooling. Queenslander houses are considered iconic to Brisbane and are typically sold at a significant premium to equivalent modern houses. The relatively low cost of timber in south-east Queensland meant that until recently
column7: most residences were constructed of timber
column8: rather than brick or stone. Early legislation decreed a minimum size for residential blocks leading to few terrace houses being constructed in Brisbane. The high-density housing that historically existed came in the form of miniature Queenslander-style houses which resemble the much larger traditional styles
column9: but are sometimes only one-quarter the size. These houses are most common in the inner-city suburbs.

column1: Brisbane is home to several of Australia's tallest buildings and it is ranked among world cities with the most skyscrapers. All of Brisbane's skyscrapers (buildings with a height greater than 150 metres) are located within the CBD
column2: with large numbers of high-rise buildings also proliferating in the inner suburbs of South Brisbane
column3: Kangaroo Point
column4: Fortitude Valley
column5: Newstead
column6: Teneriffe
column13: Taringa
column15: West End and Woolloongabba. Brisbane's 91-metre City Hall was the city's tallest building for decades after its completion in 1930 and was finally surpassed in 1970
column16: which marked the beginning of the widespread construction of high-rise buildings. Brisbane's tallest building is currently Brisbane Skytower
column17: which has a height of 270 metres. Architecturally prominent skyscrapers include the Harry Seidler-designed Riparian Plaza
column19: which incorporates LED lighting resembling the buttress roots of the Moreton Bay fig
column21: the executive headquarters of the Queensland Government.

Brisbane's Greater Capital City Statistical Area includes the Local Government Areas of City of Brisbane
column2: City of Ipswich

column5: as well as parts of Lockyer Valley Region

column7: which form a continuous metropolitan area. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates that the population of Greater Brisbane is 2
column10: making it the third largest city in Australia.

column1: The 2016 census showed that 32.2% of Brisbane's inhabitants were born overseas and 50.9% of inhabitants had at least one parent born overseas. Brisbane has the 26th largest immigrant population among world metropolitan areas. Of inhabitants born outside of Australia

column3: England
column4: Mainland China
column5: and India. Brisbane has the largest New Zealand and Taiwanese-born populations of any city in Australia.The areas of Sunnybank

column15: with Chinese being the most commonly-reported ancestry in each of these areas. The Vietnamese-born are the largest immigrant group in Inala

At the 2016 census
column2: 78% of inhabitants spoke only English at home

column4: Vietnamese (1.0%)

column1: === Religion ===
At the 2016 census
column2: the most commonly cited religious affiliation was 'No religion' (30.6%).Brisbane's most popular religion at the 2016 census was Christianity
column3: and the most popular denominations were Catholicism (21.5%) and Anglicanism (13.3%). Other Christian denominations including Uniting Church
column4: Baptists
column5: Pentecostalism
column6: Lutheranism and Eastern Orthodox made up 18.8% of the population. All Christian denominations totalled 53.6% of the population. Brisbane's CBD is home to two cathedrals – St John's (Anglican) and St Stephen's (Catholic).

column1: The most popular non-Christian religions at the 2016 census were Buddhist (2%)
column2: Muslim (1.5%) and Hindu (1.5%).

column1: == Economy ==
Categorised as a global city
column2: Brisbane is among Asia-Pacific cities with largest GDPs and is one of the major business hubs in Australia
column3: with strengths in mining
column4: banking
column5: insurance
column6: transportation
column8: real estate and food.Some of the largest companies headquartered in Brisbane
column13: Bank of Queensland
column27: Collins Foods and Boeing Australia. Most major Australian companies
column28: as well as numerous international companies

column1: Brisbane throughout its history has been one of Australia's most important seaport cities. The Port of Brisbane located at the Brisbane River's mouth on Moreton Bay and on the adjacent Fisherman's Island
column2: created by means of land reclamation. It is the 3rd busiest port in Australia for value of goods. Container freight
column3: sugar
column4: grain
column5: coal and bulk liquids are the major exports. Most of the port facilities are less than three decades old and some are built on reclaimed mangroves and wetlands. The Port is a part of the Australia TradeCoast
column6: which includes the Brisbane Airport along with large industrial estates located along both banks at the mouth of the Brisbane River.White-collar industries include information technology
column8: higher education and public sector administration generally concentrated in and around the central business district and satellite hubs located in the inner suburbs such as South Brisbane

column1: Blue-collar industries
column2: including petroleum refining
column3: stevedoring
column4: paper milling
column5: metalworking and QR railway workshops
column6: tend to be located on the lower reaches of the Brisbane River proximal to the Port of Brisbane and in new industrial zones on the urban fringe.

column1: Tourism is an important part of the Brisbane economy
column2: both in its own right and as a gateway to other areas of Queensland
column3: as international education
column4: with over 95
column5: 000 international students enrolled in universities and other tertiary education institutions in the central City of Brisbane local government area alone in 2018.

column1: === Retail ===
Retail in the CBD is centred around the Queen Street Mall
column2: which is Queensland's largest pedestrian mall. Shopping centres in the CBD include the Myer Centre
column3: the Wintergarden
column4: MacArthur Central and QueensPlaza
column5: with the last of these along with Edward Street forming the city's focus for luxury brands. There are historical shopping arcades at Brisbane Arcade and Tattersalls Arcade. Suburbs adjacent to the CBD such as Fortitude Valley (particularly James Street)
column6: South Brisbane and West End are also a major inner-city retail hubs.

column1: Outside of the inner-city
column2: retail is focused on indoor shopping centres
column3: including numerous regional shopping centres along with six super regional shopping centres
column4: all of which are among Australia's largest
column5: namely: Westfield Chermside in the north; Westfield Garden City in the south; Westfield Carindale in the east; Indooroopilly Shopping Centre in the west; Westfield North Lakes in the outer-north; and Logan Hyperdome in the outer-south. Brisbane's major factory outlet centres are the Direct Factory Outlets at Skygate and Jindalee.

column1: The 100 hectare Brisbane Markets at Rocklea are Brisbane's largest wholesale markets
column2: whilst smaller markets operate at numerous locations throughout the city including South Bank Parklands
column3: Davies Park in West End
column4: Queensland and the Eat Street Markets at Hamilton.

column1: == Culture and sport ==
Brisbane is home to several art galleries
column2: the largest of which are the Queensland Art Gallery and the Queensland Gallery of Modern Art (GOMA)
column3: which is the largest modern art gallery in Australia. GOMA holds the Asia Pacific Triennial (APT) which focuses on contemporary art from the Asia and Pacific in a variety of media from painting to video work. In Addition
column4: its size enables the gallery to exhibit particularly large shows.

column1: Dramatic and musical theatre performances are held at the multiple large theatres located at Queensland Performing Arts Centre (QPAC). The Brisbane Powerhouse in New Farm and the Judith Wright Arts Centre in Fortitude Valley also feature diverse programmes featuring exhibitions and festivals of visual art
column2: music and dance. Brisbane is also home to numerous small theatres including the Brisbane Arts Theatre in Petrie Terrace
column3: the La Boite Theatre Company which performs at the Roundhouse Theatre at Kelvin Grove
column4: the Twelfth Night Theatre at Bowen Hills
column5: the Metro Arts Theatre in Edward Street
column6: and the Queensland Theatre Company's Bille Brown Theatre in West End.

column1: The Queensland Performing Arts Centre (QPAC) at South Bank
column2: consists of the Lyric Theatre
column3: the Concert Hall
column4: the Cremorne Theatre and the Playhouse Theatre and is home to the Queensland Ballet
column5: Opera Queensland
column6: the Queensland Theatre Company
column7: and the Queensland Symphony Orchestra. The Queensland Conservatorium
column8: a musical conservatorium in which professional music companies and conservatorium students also stage performances
column9: is located within the South Bank Parklands. Numerous choirs present performances across the city annually. These choirs include the Brisbane Chorale
column13: Brisbane Concert Choir
column14: Imogen Children's Chorale and Brisbane Birralee Voices.

column1: Brisbane has maintained a constantly evolving live music scene
column2: producing acts spanning genres including punk (see Brisbane punk rock)
column3: indie rock
column4: electronic music
column5: experimental music
column6: noise rock
column7: metal and post-punk. Brisbane's live music history is often intertwined with social unrest and authoritarian politics
column8: as retold by journalist Andrew Stafford in Pig City: From The Saints to Savage Garden
column10: edited by academics Raymond Evans and Carole Ferrier
column11: and BNE – The Definitive Archive: Brisbane Independent Electronic Music Production 1979–2014
column12: produced by record label director Dennis Remmer. There are also popular entertainment pubs and clubs within both the City and Fortitude Valley. The Brisbane Entertainment Centre at Boondall is an arena which hosts many musical concerts
column13: with some of the largest being held at Lang Park.

column1: Musicians from Brisbane include the Bee Gees (raised in Redcliffe and Cribb Island)
column2: Powderfinger (who met at Brisbane Grammar School and the University of Queensland)
column3: The Go-Betweens (after whom Brisbane's Go Between Bridge is named
column4: and whose songs and albums
column5: such as Spring Hill Fair
column6: reflect the attitude of 1980s Brisbane)
column7: The Veronicas (born and raised in Albany Creek)
column9: one of the first punk rock bands)
column13: Ball Park Music
column14: and Twoset Violin. The city is featured in music including The Saints' "Brisbane (Security City)" (1978); The Stranglers' "Nuclear Device" (1979) about Joh Bjelke-Petersen; Midnight Oil's single "Dreamworld" (1987); and Powderfinger's album Vulture Street (2003).

column1: Prominent writers from Brisbane include David Malouf (whose 1975 novel Johnno is set in Brisbane and at Brisbane Grammar School during World War II)
column2: Nick Earls (whose 1996 novel Zigzag Street is set at Zigzag Street in Red Hill)
column3: and Li Cunxin
column4: author of Mao's Last Dancer and artistic director of the Queensland Ballet. The State Library of Queensland
column5: the state's largest library
column6: is located at the Queensland Cultural Centre.

column1: Brisbane is home to over 6
column2: 000 restaurants and dining establishments
column3: with outdoor dining featuring prominently. The most popular cuisines by number of dining establishments are Japanese
column4: Chinese
column5: Modern Australian
column6: Italian
column10: less commonly known as flathead lobsters
column11: are an ingredient named for the Brisbane region and which feature commonly in the city's cuisine
column13: also native to the region.

column1: === Annual events ===
The Royal Queensland Exhibition (known locally as the Ekka)
column2: an agricultural exhibition held each August at the Brisbane Showgrounds in Bowen Hills is the longest-running major annual event held in Brisbane
column3: during which there is a public holiday for each local government area across Brisbane so as to enable widespread public attendance.

column1: The Brisbane Festival
column2: which includes one of the nation's largest annual fireworks displays called 'Riverfire'
column3: and which is held each September at South Bank Parklands
column4: the CBD and surrounding areas is the second of Brisbane's major annual events
column5: with the 'Riverfire' fireworks displays attended by hundreds of thousands of residents annually.

column1: The Brisbane International Film Festival (BIFF) is held in July/August each year in a variety of venues around Brisbane. BIFF features new films and retrospectives by domestic and international filmmakers along with seminars and awards.
The Buddha Birth Day festival at South Bank parklands attracts over 200
column2: 000 visitors each year
column3: and is the largest event of its type in Australia.

column1: There are also many smaller community events such as the Paniyiri festival (a Greek cultural festival held over two days in May)
column2: the Brisbane Medieval Fayre and Tournament (held each June)
column3: the Bridge to Brisbane charity fun run
column4: the Anywhere Festival and

column1: the Caxton Street Seafood and Wine Festival.
Major events are often held at the 171
column2: 000 square metre Brisbane Convention & Exhibition Centre in South Brisbane.

column1: === Sport ===
Brisbane has hosted several major sporting events including the 1982 Commonwealth Games and the 2001 Goodwill Games
column2: as well as events during the 1987 Rugby World Cup
column3: 1992 Cricket World Cup
column4: 2000 Sydney Olympics
column5: 2003 Rugby World Cup
column6: 2008 Rugby League World Cup
column7: 2017 Rugby League World Cup and the 2018 Commonwealth Games. It holds the Brisbane International tennis competition every year.

column1: Rugby league is popular in Brisbane and the city hosts the Brisbane Broncos
column2: who play in the National Rugby League competition and the Queensland Maroons who play in the State of Origin series.

column1: In rugby union the city hosts the Queensland Reds who play in the Super Rugby competition.
Cricket is popular in the Brisbane and the city hosts the Brisbane Heat who play in the Big Bash League and the Queensland Bulls who play in the Sheffield Shield and the Ryobi One Day Cup.
Brisbane also hosts an A-League soccer team
column2: the Brisbane Roar FC; an Australian Football League team
column3: the Brisbane Lions; a basketball team
column4: the Brisbane Bullets; a baseball team
column5: the Brisbane Bandits; a netball team
column6: the Queensland Firebirds; a field hockey team
column7: the Brisbane Blaze; and water polo teams the Brisbane Barracudas and Queensland Breakers.

column1: The city's major stadiums and sporting venues include the Gabba (a 42
column2: 000 seat round stadium at Woolloongabba)
column3: Lang Park (a 52
column4: 500 seat rectangular stadium at Milton also known by its corporate name Suncorp Stadium)
column5: Ballymore Stadium
column6: the Queensland Sport and Athletics Centre
column9: the Eagle Farm Racecourse and the Doomben Racecourse. The city is also home to numerous golf courses
column10: with the largest being the Indooroopilly Golf Club at Indooroopilly
column12: the Brookwater Golf and Country Club at Brookwater
column13: the Keperra Country Golf Club at Keperra and the Royal Queensland Golf Club at Eagle Farm.

column1: In addition to its flagship sport franchises
column2: Brisbane and its regions and suburbs have numerous teams in secondary leagues including the Intrust Super Cup
column3: National Rugby Championship
column4: Queensland Premier Rugby
column5: National Premier League Queensland
column6: North East Australian Football League
column11: National Water Polo League and F-league.

column1: == Tourism and recreation ==
Tourism plays a major role in Brisbane's economy
column2: being the third-most popular destination for international tourists after Sydney and Melbourne. Popular tourist and recreation areas in Brisbane include the South Bank Parklands (including the Wheel of Brisbane)
column3: the City Botanic Gardens
column4: Roma Street Parkland
column5: New Farm Park
column6: the Howard Smith Wharves
column9: Fortitude Valley (including James Street and Chinatown)
column11: City Hall (including the Museum of Brisbane)
column13: the Story Bridge and bridge climb; St John's Cathedral
column14: ANZAC Square and the Queensland Cultural Centre (including the Queensland Museum
column17: the Gallery of Modern Art and the State Library of Queensland)
column18: the Kangaroo Point Cliffs and park

column1: Brisbane is notable for its Brisbane Riverwalk network
column2: which runs along much of the Brisbane River foreshore throughout the inner-city area
column3: with the longest span running between Newstead and Toowong. Another popular stretch runs beneath the Kangaroo Point Cliffs between South Brisbane and Kangaroo Point. Several spans of the Riverwalk are built out over the Brisbane River.  Brisbane also has over 27 km (17 mi) of bicycle pathways
column4: mostly surrounding the Brisbane River and city centre. Other popular recreation activities include the Story Bridge adventure climb and rock climbing at the Kangaroo Point Cliffs.

column1: Moreton Bay and its marine park is also a major attraction
column2: and its three primary islands Moreton Island
column3: North Stradbroke Island and Bribie Island
column4: accessible by ferry
column5: contain popular surf beaches and resorts. Tangalooma resort on Moreton Island is popular for its nightly wild dolphin feeding attraction
column6: and for operating Australia's longest running whale watching cruises. The Fort Lytton National Park including a colonial defence fort and museum is also a historical bayside attraction. Beachside suburbs such as those on the Redcliffe Peninsula
column10: Manly and Wellington Point are also popular attractions for their bayside beaches
column13: sailing

column1: The Mount Coot-tha Reserve
column2: including Mount Coot-tha
column3: the Mount Coot-tha Lookout
column4: the Mount Coot-tha Botanic Gardens and the Sir Thomas Brisbane Planetarium is a popular recreational attraction for hiking and bushwalking.

column1: There are many national parks surrounding the Brisbane metropolitan area which are popular recreational attractions for hiking and bushwalking. The D'Aguilar National Park runs along the northwest of the metropolitan area in the D'Aguilar Range
column2: and contains popular bushwalking and hiking peaks at Mount Nebo
column3: Camp Mountain
column4: Mount Pleasant
column5: Mount Glorious
column6: Mount Samson and Mount Mee. The Glass House Mountains National Park is located to the north of the metropolitan area in the Glass House Mountains between it and that of the Sunshine Coast. The Tamborine National Park at Tamborine Mountain is located in the Gold Coast hinterland to the south of the metropolitan area. Moreton
column7: North Stradbroke and Bribie islands are substantially covered by the Moreton Island National Park
column8: Naree Budjong Djara National Park and the Bribie Island National Park respectively. The Boondall Wetlands in the suburb of Boondall are protected mangrove wetlands with floating walking trails.

column1: Immediately to the south and north of Brisbane are the Gold Coast and Sunshine Coast respectively
column2: which are home to several of Australia's most popular swimming and surfing beaches
column3: and are popular day and weekend destinations for Brisbanites.

column2: a competition by travel guidebook Rough Guides saw Brisbane elected as one of the top ten most beautiful cities in the world
column3: citing reasons such as "its winning combination of high-rise modern architecture
column4: lush green spaces and the enormous Brisbane River that snakes its way through the centre before emptying itself into the azure Moreton Bay".

column1: == Governance ==
Unlike other Australian capital cities
column2: a large portion of the greater metropolitan area
column3: or Greater Capital City Statistical Area (GCCSA) of Brisbane is controlled by a single local government area
column4: the City of Brisbane
column5: which is the largest local government area (in terms of population and budget) in Australia
column6: serving more than 40% of the GCCSA's population. It was formed by the merger of twenty smaller LGAs in 1925
column8: 367 km2 (528 sq mi). The remainder of the metropolitan area falls into the LGAs of Logan City to the south
column9: Moreton Bay Region in the northern suburbs
column10: the City of Ipswich to the south west
column11: Redland City to the south east
column13: Scenic Rim and Lockyer Valley regions on the urban periphery. Several of these are also among the nation's most populous LGAs.

column1: Each LGA is governed under a similar structure
column2: including a directly elected mayor (including the Lord Mayor of Brisbane)
column3: as well as a council composed of councillors representing geographical wards. City Hall is the seat of the Brisbane City Council
column4: the governing corporation of the City of Brisbane LGA
column5: and the bulk of its executive offices are located at the Brisbane Square skyscraper.

column1: As the capital city of Queensland
column2: Brisbane is home to the Parliament of Queensland at Parliament House at Gardens Point in the CBD
column3: adjacent to Old Government House. Queensland's current Government House is located in Paddington. The bulk of the state government's executive offices are located at the 1 William Street skyscraper. The Queensland Supreme and District courts are located at the Queen Elizabeth II Courts of Law in George Street
column4: while the Magistrates court is located at the adjacent Brisbane Magistrates Court building. The various federal courts are loced at the Commonwealth Law Courts building on North Quay.

column1: The Australian Army's Enoggera Barracks is located in Enoggera
column2: while the historic Victoria Barracks in Petrie Terrace now hosts a military museum. The Royal Australian Navy's HMAS Moreton base is located at Bulimba. The Royal Australian Air Force's RAAF Base Amberley is located in Amberley in the outer south-west of the metropolitan area.

column1: Brisbane's largest prisons and correctional facilities
column2: the Brisbane Correctional Centre
column3: Brisbane Women's Correctional Centre
column4: Arthur Gorrie Correctional Centre and Wolston Correctional Centre are located at Wacol
column5: while the city's main historical prison
column6: the Boggo Road Gaol

column1: == Education ==
There are five major multi-campus universities with campuses in Brisbane's metropolitan area
column2: namely:

column1: The University of Queensland (UQ)
column2: which is Queensland's oldest university and frequently ranks among the world's top 50
column3: with campuses in St Lucia
column4: Herston and Gatton

column1: Queensland University of Technology (QUT)
column2: with campuses in the central business district (Gardens Point) and Kelvin Grove

column1: Griffith University (GU)
column2: with campuses in Nathan
column3: Mount Gravatt
column4: South Bank and Meadowbrook

column1: The University of Southern Queensland (USQ)
column2: with campuses in Springfield and Ipswich

column1: The University of the Sunshine Coast (USC)
column2: with campuses in Petrie and CabooltureOther universities which have campuses in Brisbane include the Australian Catholic University
column3: Central Queensland University
column4: James Cook University and the University of the Sunshine Coast.

column1: Brisbane is a major destination for international students
column2: who constitute a large proportion of enrolments in Brisbane's universities and are important to the city's economy and real estate market. In 2018
column3: there were over 95
column4: 000 international students enrolled in universities and other tertiary education institutions in the central City of Brisbanel local government area alone. The majority of Brisbane's international students originate from China
column5: India and other countries in the Asia-Pacific region.There are biotechnology and research facilities at several universities in Brisbane
column6: including the Institute for Molecular Bioscience and CSIRO at the University of Queensland and the Institute of Health and Biomedical Innovation at Queensland University of Technology.There are three major TAFE colleges in Brisbane; the Brisbane North Institute of TAFE
column7: the Metropolitan South Institute of TAFE
column8: and the Southbank Institute of TAFE. Brisbane is also home to numerous other independent tertiary providers
column9: including the Australian College of Natural Medicine
column13: Jschool: Journalism Education & Training
column15: and American College and the Aboriginal Centre for the Performing Arts.

column1: Many of Brisbane's pre-school
column2: primary
column3: and secondary schools are under the jurisdiction of Education Queensland
column4: a branch of the Queensland Government. Independent (private)
column5: Roman Catholic and other religious schools also constitute a large share of Brisbane's primary and secondary schooling sectors
column6: with the oldest such independent schools composing the memberships of the Great Public Schools Association of Queensland (GPS) for boys' schools and Queensland Girls' Secondary Schools Sports Association (QGSSSA) for girls' schools.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Transport ===
Brisbane has an extensive transportation network within the city
column2: as well as connections to regional centres
column3: interstate and to overseas destinations. Like all Australian cities
column4: the most popular mode of transport is private car. Public transport is provided by rail
column5: bus and ferry services and is co-ordinated by TransLink
column6: which provides a unified ticketing and electronic payment system (known as 'go card') for South East Queensland. The region is divided into seven fare zones radiating outwards from the Brisbane central business district (CBD)
column7: with Brisbane's built-up area falling within zones 1–3. Bus services are operated by public and private operators whereas trains and ferries are operated by public agencies. The CBD is the central hub for all public transport services with services focusing on Roma Street
column8: Central and Fortitude Valley railway stations; King George Square
column9: Queen Street and Roma Street busway stations; and North Quay
column10: Riverside and QUT Gardens Point ferry wharves.

column1: Brisbane is served by a large network of urban and inter-urban motorways. The Pacific Motorway (M3/M1) connects the inner-city with the southern suburbs
column2: Gold Coast and New South Wales. The Ipswich Motorway (M7/M2) connects the inner-city with the outer south-western suburbs. The Western Freeway and Centenary Motorway (M5) connect the city's inner-west and outer south-west. The Bruce Highway and Gympie Arterial Road (M1/M3) connect the city's northern suburbs with the Sunshine Coast and northern Queensland. The Logan Motorway (M2/M6) connects the southern and south-western suburbs. The Gateway Motorway is a toll road which connects the Gold and Sunshine Coast. The Port of Brisbane Motorway links the Gateway Motorway to the Port of Brisbane. The Inner City Bypass and Riverside Expressway serve as an inner ring freeway system to prevent motorists from travelling through the city's congested centre.Brisbane also has a large network of major road tunnels under the metropolitan area
column3: known as the TransApex network
column4: which include the Clem Jones Tunnel between the inner-north and inner-south
column5: the Airport Link tunnel in the north-east and the Legacy Way tunnel in the south-west. They are the three longest road tunnels in Australia.

column1: ==== Bridges ====
The Brisbane River creates a barrier to road transport routes. In total there are sixteen bridges over the river
column2: mostly concentrated in the inner city area. The road bridges (which usually also include provision for pedestrians and cyclists) by distance from the river mouth are the Sir Leo Hielscher Bridges
column3: the Story Bridge
column4: the Captain Cook Bridge
column5: the Victoria Bridge
column6: the William Jolly Bridge
column9: the Walter Taylor Bridge the Centenary Bridge and Colleges Crossing. There are three railway bridges
column11: the Albert Bridge and the Indooroopilly Railway Bridge. There are also three pedestrian only bridges: the Goodwill Bridge
column12: the Kurilpa Bridge and the Jack Pesch Bridge.

column1: The Houghton Highway (northbound) and Ted Smout Memorial Bridge (southbound) bridges
column2: over Bramble Bay between Brighton and the Redcliffe Peninsula
column3: are the longest bridges in the state. The abutment arches of the original crossing The Hornibrook Bridge still remain in place.

column1: The Queensland Rail City network consists of 152 train stations along 13 suburban rail lines and across the metropolitan area
column2: namely: the Airport line; the Beenleigh line; the Caboolture line; the Cleveland line; the Doomben line; the Exhibition line; the Ferny Grove line; the Ipswich/Rosewood line; the Redcliffe Peninsula line; the Shorncliffe line; and the Springfield line. The network extends to the Gold and Sunshine coasts
column3: which are fully integrated into the network on the Gold Coast line and Sunshine Coast line. The Airtrain service which runs on the Airport line is jointly operated between the City of Brisbane and Brisbane Airport.

column1: 55 million passenger trips were taken across the network in 2018–19.Construction of the network began in 1865 and has been progressively expanded in the subsequent centuries. Electrification of the network was completed between 1979 and 1988. The Cross River Rail project includes a twin rail tunnel (5.9 kilometres (3.7 mi) long) which will pass under the Brisbane River to link two new railway stations at Albert Street in the CBD and Wooloongabba is under construction and scheduled to be completed in 2024.
Brisbane has a large dedicated bus rapid transit network
column2: the Brisbane busway network. The network comprises the South East Busway
column3: the Northern Busway and the Eastern Busway. The main network hubs are the King George Square
column4: Queen Street
column5: and Roma Street busway stations.

column1: There are also numerous suburban bus routes operating throughout the metropolitan area
column2: including the high-frequency Blue and Maroon CityGlider routes which run between Newstead and West End (Blue)
column3: and Ashgrove and Stones Corner (Maroon) respectively.

column1: Transdev Brisbane Ferries operates three ferry services along the Brisbane River
column2: CityCat
column3: CityFerry and CityHopper. Brisbane's ferries
column4: and particularly its catamaran CityCats
column5: are considered iconic to the city.The CityCat high-speed catamaran ferry service
column6: popular with tourists and commuters
column7: operates services along the Brisbane River between the University of Queensland and Northshore Hamilton
column8: with wharves at UQ St Lucia
column13: North Quay

column1: The CityFerry service operates smaller vessels for popular cross-river routes
column2: namely: Bulimba–Teneriffe
column3: New Farm Park–Norman Park
column4: and Holman Street–Eagle Street Pier–Thornton Street.

column1: The free CityHopper service operates smaller vessels along a route between North Quay and Sydney Street
column2: stopping at South Bank
column3: Maritime Museum
column4: Thornton Street
column5: Eagle Street Pier
column6: Holman Street and Dockside.

column1: ==== Pedestrian ====
An extensive network of pedestrian and cyclist pathways span the banks of the Brisbane River in the inner suburbs to form the Riverwalk network. In some segments
column2: the Riverwalk is built over the river. The longest span of the Riverwalk connects Newstead in the east with Toowong in the west.

column1: ==== Airports ====
Brisbane Airport (IATA code: BNE) is the city's main airport
column2: the third busiest in Australia after Sydney Airport and Melbourne Airport. It is located north-east of the city centre on Moreton Bay and provides domestic and international passenger services. In the 2017
column3: Brisbane Airport handled over 23 million passengers. The airport is an airline hub for Qantas
column4: Virgin Australia and Jetstar as well as a number of minor and freight airlines. The airport is served by the Airtrain service which runs on the Airport line
column5: providing a direct service to the CBD.

column1: Archerfield Airport in Brisbane's southern suburbs
column2: Redcliffe Airport  on the Redcliffe Peninsula and Caboolture Airfield in the far north of the metropolitan area serve Brisbane as general aviation airports.

column1: Brisbane is also served by other major airports in South East Queensland
column2: including Gold Coast Airport at Coolangatta
column3: Sunshine Coast Airport at Marcoola and Toowoomba Wellcamp Airport at Wellcamp.

column1: ==== Seaport ====
The Port of Brisbane is located at the mouth of the Brisbane River on Moreton Bay and on the adjacent Fisherman's Island
column2: an artificial island created by land reclamation. It is the third busiest port in Australia for value of goods. The port is the endpoint of the main shipping channel across Moreton Bay which extends 90 kilometres north near Mooloolaba. The port has 29 operating berths including nine deep-water container berths and three deep-water bulk berths as well as 17 bulk and general cargo berths.

column1: There are two cruise ship terminals in Brisbane. Portside Wharf at Hamilton is an international standard facility for cruise liners. Due to the height of the Gateway Bridge which must be passed to reach the terminal
column2: the wharf services small and medium-sized cruise ships. The Brisbane International Cruise Terminal at Luggage Point in Pinkenba is able to accommodate the largest cruise vessels in the world
column3: and will be opened in 2020.

column1: === Healthcare ===
Brisbane is covered by Queensland Health's "Metro North" and "Metro South" Health Service Networks. Within the greater Brisbane area there are eight major public hospitals
column2: four major private hospitals
column3: and numerous smaller public and private facilities. The Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital and the Princess Alexandra Hospital are two of Queensland's three major trauma centres. Standing alone
column4: they are the largest hospitals in Australia. The Princess Alexandra Hospital houses the Translational Research Institute (Australia) along with the state's renal and liver transplant services. The Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital includes a specialist burns unit.  The Prince Charles Hospital is the state's major cardiac transplant centre. Other major public hospitals include the Mater Hospital
column5: the Queen Elizabeth II Jubilee Hospital
column6: and the Queensland Children's Hospital.

column1: Specialist and general medical practices are located in the CBD
column2: and most suburbs and localities.

column1: Brisbane is also home to the headquarters of the Queensland Ambulance Service central executive
column2: located at the Emergency Services Complex Kedron Park
column3: along with the headquarters of the Queensland Fire and Emergency Services and the Queensland Emergency Operations Centre.

column1: === Other utilities ===
Water storage
column2: treatment and delivery for Brisbane is handled by SEQ Water
column3: which sells on to Queensland Urban Utilities (previously Brisbane Water) for distribution to the greater Brisbane area. Water for the area is stored in three major dams to the north-west of the metropolitan area: Wivenhoe
column4: Somerset and North Pine.

column1: There is an open market in relation to the supply of electricity and gas in Brisbane with the largest providers being Energex (electricity) and Origin Energy (gas).
Metropolitan Brisbane is serviced by all major and most minor telecommunications companies and their networks
column2: including Telstra
column3: Optus and Vodafone Australia.

column1: Brisbane is home to numerous cemeteries including the following large 19th-century historical cemeteries: the 44-hectare Toowong Cemetery (the largest cemetery in Queensland
column2: which is a popular destination for walkers and joggers)
column3: Balmoral Cemetery
column4: Lutwyche Cemetery
column5: Nudgee Cemetery
column6: Nundah Cemetery and South Brisbane Cemetery.

column1: == Media ==
=== Print ===
The main local print newspapers of Brisbane are The Courier-Mail and its sibling The Sunday Mail
column2: both owned by News Corporation. Brisbane also receives the national daily
column3: The Australian
column4: its sibling the Weekend Australian
column5: as well as The Australian Financial Review. Sydney's The Sydney Morning Herald and Melbourne's The Age also sell in Brisbane in smaller numbers.

column1: The Brisbane Times is Brisbane's second major local news source
column2: owned by Nine
column3: and is online only.

column1: There are community and suburban newspapers throughout the metropolitan area
column2: including Brisbane News and City News
column3: many of which are produced by Quest Community Newspapers.

column1: === Television ===
Brisbane is served by all five major television networks in Australia
column2: which broadcast from prominent television transmission towers on the summit of Mount Coot-tha. The three commercial stations
column3: Seven
column4: Nine
column5: and Ten
column6: are accompanied by two government networks
column7: ABC and SBS. Channels provided by these networks include 10 Bold
column13: ABC ME
column17: SBS Viceland HD (SBS Viceland broadcast in HD)
column31: also broadcasts in Brisbane. Optus and Foxtel operate PayTV services in Brisbane

column1: === Radio ===
Brisbane is serviced by five major public radio stations including major commercial radio stations
column2: including 612 ABC Brisbane (local news
column3: current affairs and talk); ABC Radio National (national news and current affairs); ABC NewsRadio (national news); ABC Classic FM (classical music);   Triple J (alternative music); and SBS Radio (multicultural broadcasting).

column1: Brisbane is serviced by numerous major commercial and community radio stations including 4BC (local and national talk
column2: news and current affairs); 4KQ (oldies); Magic 882 (oldies); 4BH; 97.3 (pop); B105 (pop); Nova 106.9 (pop); Triple M (rock); 96five Family FM (pop); Radio TAB (betting) and 4MBS (classical).

column1: Brisbane is also serviced by community radio stations such as VAC Radio (Mandarin); Radio Brisvaani (Hindi); Radio Arabic (Arabic); 4EB (multiple languages); 98.9 FM (indigenous); 4RPH (vision impaired); Switch 1197 (youth broadcasting); 4ZZZ (community radio); and Vision Christian Radio (Christian).  Additional channels are also available via DAB digital radio.
